message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for complement component C3d, which enhances the entry of EBV into B cells, so the pathogenesis of EBV would most likely be affected by the genetic modification of B cells not expressing CD21. Measles virus infects respiratory epithelial cells, HIV infects T cells, and human papillomavirus infects epithelial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, and its absence on B cells would likely impair the immune response to EBV. Measles virus does not involve CD21, while HIV and HPV target different cells in the immune system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, therefore, if B cells are genetically modified to not express CD21, the pathogenesis of Epstein-Barr virus would likely be affected. The other options do not have a specific connection to CD21.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 plays a role in the immune response to Epstein-Barr virus, so a genetic modification that prevents its expression on B cells would most likely affect the pathogenesis of EBV. CD21 is not involved in the immune response to the other options listed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for the Epstein-Barr virus, so the genetic modification of B cells to not express CD21 would most likely affect the pathogenesis of this virus. CD21 is not involved in the pathogenesis of the other options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for the Epstein-Barr virus, so its absence would affect the pathogenesis of the virus. The other options do not use CD21 as a receptor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor that B cells use to bind to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), so if B cells are modified to not express CD21, the pathogenesis of EBV would most likely be affected. Measles virus uses another receptor to bind to B cells, and HIV and human papillomavirus do not infect B cells directly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for complement component C3d, which helps B cells to recognize antigen, process antigen, and present peptide-MHC complexes to helper T-cells. Epstein-Barr virus interacts with CD21 to infect B cells, so genetic modification that eliminates CD21 expression on B cells would impede the pathogenesis of Epstein-Barr virus in these cells. The other organisms are not known to directly interact with CD21.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for the Epstein-Barr virus, so if B cells are genetically modified to not express it, the pathogenesis of EBV would be affected. The other viruses listed do not rely on CD21 for their pathogenesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD21 is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus, therefore if B cells do not express it, the pathogenesis of this virus would most likely be affected. CD21 receptors are not important for the pathogenesis of the other viruses listed.
